segments.text: I went to a place in Monaco where they give you a day's instruction.
Not enough, but I got a rough idea if I worked and I tried to write on it and I thought I was writing badly because
There was no sense of muscular effort, and that applies also to using an electric car, right?
I like to feel that I'm... It's rather like playing the piano.
I like to feel your muscles going into it.
And I just was not writing well.
There was no sensation of creating anything.
And I noticed that with one or two writers, their style has deteriorated.
Albin Tochter wrote a recent book, wrote a third wave.
He said in the middle, I have now started writing this on a word post.
And you can see the drop in the quality inside.
Come on, it's black.
It's black.

you know george lex 10th novel george mills might scan the opens well i know he's not the only one i mean uh our writer uh len dapney you know when his last book was called goodbye mickey mouse he's been using one of these for a long time and uh he admits to me that there's certain
Lack of tension.
You know, it's as though you're leaving it to the machine and your brain sort of turns off.
Your brain's there, you know.
I think it's marvellous revision.
Yes, I'm a bad reviser because I waste a lot of paper.
When I write a novel, I... You're leaving a lot of varying... Well, you know what happens, you sit down, you put the paper in the machine and say, right, I've got to start writing a novel.
So you type one.
That's all right.
One at the top right hand corner, you're all right, you're written.
Then you put chapter one, or just O-N-E, underlined.
And then you attempt a sentence, and this is bad.
tear it up, start again, and eventually you get a third sentence, then you get on to a second sentence, and that's no good.
You know, this takes about, I waste about 20 or more sheets in just trying to get a first page.
All the time we've got a first page, I tend to say, you know, that's it.
Nobody else wants to touch that.
That's as good as I can make it.
I'm just going to test and see how we're doing.
That's fine.
I think it's a different matter with journalism.
I think that writing an article, you don't worry quite as much about qualities of style or accuracy, as you should.
Well, the deadlines.
The deadlines, the deadlines are important.
I'm very fond of deadlines.
I love deadlines.
i get these quite a lot in in europe you know i i bought certainly two newspapers one is the daily mail in london the other is uh the corriere la sera is made in the land and they
When some event takes place, like, you know, the attempted assassination of the Pope, you see, they write, well, you want 2,000 words in one hour.
I love that.
I myself wonder.
I love that.
I know that I can't spare the time to write too well.
You know, you can't search for it.
That's an interesting statement.
Well, surely.
It makes the style flow.
The style is highly colloquial.
When you read it, you're horrified.
That's what's horrified to read it.
There was a piece you had in the New York Times, I think, in the last summer, in the living section on food.
Oh, yes.
Oh, I clipped it.
I used to be a restaurant reviewer.
I do this occasionally.
When do you know all about it?
Well, I'm a cook.
I do the cooking.
I do the cooking at home.
And my son is a restaurant cook.
Oh, I do.
He's in here.
I trained by the French.
I was a worker.
But...
Where does he work?
Well, he worked at perhaps the best restaurant in the world, which is Phuket, you know, on the Champs-Élysées in Paris.
They call it a brigade, you know, a brigade in the picture.
There was a brigade of 50, or probably more, probably more than 50, and it becomes very personal.
And you have this autocratic chef, you know, the autocratic man who never does any cooking, he just sits in an office like a chef, a real chef.
You become part of a machine.
But he got a job in a bistro on... Ah, thank you.
In Paris.
He was his own boss in the kitchen.
He took over the kitchen.
Thank you very much.
He took over the kitchen.
He was all right at the time.
Where would you like to put that?
Oh, that's the one.
You know what?
I'm going to get in.
Where should we put it?
Oh, here as well.
Yeah, that's my shirt eggs.
Are those your shirt eggs?
Oh, thank you.
Well, that's your what?
That's right, your blueberry muffin.
Your blueberry muffin, that's right.
None of those.
I'll leave too early tomorrow to get anywhere.

The last job my son had was in the Grosvenor Health Hotel in London, which was a good hotel, a big hotel, but it was all banquets, you know, there was a banquet every day, a thousand people or two thousand, and all he was doing was
cutting cucumbers.
They gave it up.
Well, you have to learn, I guess, there's an apprenticeship in every profession.
It's a long apprenticeship in, you know, in America, well, you just go into a hash joint, I suppose, and fry eggs, but with a French, it's a very serious business.
Very serious.
The whole scope of that piece was how the same dishes
But with the French name, they sound so different.
They sound different, yes.
But there's a lot of snobbishs, if I may say, in America.
There's a lot of snobbishs in America about French food.
You know what I mean?
Faculty wives pride themselves on their gourmet cooking.
Instead of turning out very good.
American dishes.
They give you invitation.
There is fashion and food every day.
There's some very good New England dishes, like New England boiled dinner, which everyone is supposed to despise.
Have you ever tried it?
I love it.
and um there's a lot of things in boston that's strong really it's just a young medic or quite clam chowder clenched up make clam chowder boston queen pie baked thinning hatty have you ever had that
I've done the cooking in the house now for the last 15 years since my second marriage.
Because my wife is very badly brought up by her mother.
She has no domestic school.
She'll be starving.
Tell me about...

the distinction between an entertainment and a novel are we to take an entertainment not as seriously as a novel you're not to take it seriously at all in other words your attitude should be one of total relaxation and then if there's anything in the novel that should work on the subliminal level would you call this an experiment or
It is in the sense that it's an attempt to allow a visual medium to influence a verbal medium.
It's an attempt to imitate television, to imitate the process of watching television.
In one of two ways.
Either you're watching three screens at the same time, which I think will come.
I think it's going to happen.
I think we've got more information than from getting a single screen.
Do you think the powers of concentration of people are... My feeling is that they're declining, not getting... Well, they're taking in a lot of visual material.
I mean, if you consider the, you know, the Oscar Awards last night, there comes a moment when you've got to take in six or seven faces, in sets,
you know, round probably two images, one on top of the other.
People would take that in all right.
But I was thinking rather of, when you're watching television late at night, there are more commercials than earlier.

and uh you have to keep switching from one channel to another you have to you know just that switcher as a matter of fact that is what that novel is so when they when the commercial will come out on one thing you go to another you won't become adamant following three or even more uh storylines in the same time that's what it was i haven't got her 18 months old and she destroyed my switcher
Which is good.
Well, what happens now?
Well, I read the book, which I have to do anyway.
But it doesn't bother me.
As a matter of fact, I can leave the TV on in the background.
Maybe it's part of my training as a newspaper man.
I can't work without knowledge.
You can't write if you're listening to music.
Well, the rhythm's getting in the way.
That's very interesting, but you're a musician.
Well, it's true, but I can't do it.
You know, it's very tempting to tell somebody to start writing, but the rhythm could get in the way.
In a newspaper newsroom, for instance, there are certain sounds which are normal.
I know.
I know them, yes.
I've worked on a newspaper myself.

if anything improves that is not part of the normal if some workmen are in there it will destroy you you'll scream i mean you'll throw things but all the other noises yelling for coffee the machines clacking away the bells and all these other things there is a rhythm to that which is actually soothing there's also a limit to what you can take in i'm living in monaco and during the winter it's not too bad
But round about now, the noise starts on a quite remarkable scale.
We start off with a Grand Prix, and the noise of the Grand Prix surrounds us.
It's quite incredible.
And then summer comes, and the tourists come, and there's 24 hours.
24-hour traffic.
24 hours, because I'm living on the main road between East and Italy.
And 24 hours, I can't stand it.
I've got to leave.
I've reached the limit of toleration.
But the ordinary noise of the house, I like it.
Telephones, people shout.
My wife's Italian, so it's a lot of showers.
My premier literary obsession is studying Shakespeare, for me.
And I have an enormous library.
you know maybe four or five hundred volumes just on shakespeare and i've read all of your shakespeare i haven't written much but well it's written you've got a you've got a respectable shelf
And you wouldn't mind if I ask you a few questions.
Please, please do, yeah.
Couldn't please me better.
I have, in fact, used your suggestion that the 46th Psalm was written by Shakespeare, this 46th year with the 46th word from the beginning and the 46th word from King King as his signature.
That's right.
Well, I made a story out of that.
And I read that particular story.
That was published by Delaware Press, I think.
Oh, that's where you found it.
I see.
Interesting.
I wrote that story for an American homosexual living in Verona who bought a fine old hand press, an American hand press, and produces, or was producing, remarkable hand-printed books.
bound in leather, which is sold on subscription for $5,000 each, limiting the number, probably so about 80.
And I did this beautifully done.
He printed it beautifully.
I called it Will and Testament Day.

it's fairly accurate i think that um they discovered i think a man called martin seymour smith in britain discovered certain letters which seemed to prove that ben johnson had been involved in the katesby conspiracy on the inside
and pretended to become a Catholic and then renounced it all when the conspirators were caught and drank off the communion cup in the Church of England in token of his belief.
I don't see what else you can say.
That 46th Sarm business is... It's a wonderful... It can't be an accident.
And the poetry is beautiful, too.
Yes, but can you see how it connects?
No.
Especially where you point out what the earlier words were.
They weren't shaped and they weren't speared.
They weren't.
They were rattle or something.
That's right, yeah.
Well, I've just been translating that particular story into French, and I was watching imagine the difference, isn't it?
But that meant looking at the French version.
Which is quite remote, quite remote.
But the irony of the thing is, if it's ironic, is that he's a man who didn't even care whether he published his own plays in his lifetime.
Well, that's remarkable.
That's quite astonishing.
That's quite astonishing.
I did an interview last summer with Robert Giroux, the London publisher, and I will ask you the same question I asked him.
But I'll tell you what, I asked him what he answered.
I said, if you were able to summon forth Shakespeare and leave Crossroads on and bring him forward for an hour, what would you ask him?
What would you like to know?
He said, oh boy, what a question.
That is an hour.
He said, well, I would like to know, because I'm a publisher.
Why the hell didn't he ever want to publish his own works?
He said, Dad, I'd like to know.
He must have known that he was wonderful.
I don't think, I have a feeling that he'd never answer any literary questions at all.
If he said...
What's the fluctuation like in the price of land in the factory area?
It gives you probably a long learning discussion of how it had changed since 1564, you know, when it went up by one shilling in 1957, you know, etc.
I honestly don't think he'd answer any literary questions.
There's no doubt he had, though, strong artistic impulses, and what an artist, what a conscious artist.
I don't think he really gave a damn about discussions.
Except from the viewpoint of a practical dramaturgy, you know, the immediate problem of putting a thing on.

And I often feel that, you know, with Hamlet, there must have been a hell of a row between him and Dick Berkey, who, I'll tell you what, the producer produced these things, over Troilus and Gressler, where he only had one performance.
And, you know, if you read the quarto, it says, this was never clapper-clawed by the multitude.
You know, nobody likes it, I think, in other words.
I don't think it holds up as a play, though, do you?
Well, it's a remarkable poem, you know.
As a play, I don't know.
It depends how it's produced.
But I feel sure that there was a lot of stuff.
he wrote for a transgressor, which was cut.
Verbage insisted it be cut.
Thank you.
Thank you.
And Shakespeare said that he's not going to get away with that.
I'm going to put that back in the next way.
And when it came to Hamlet, I put it all back in again.
You know, we had this long, long visit with Hecuba.
Beautiful, but quite irrelevant.
And Shakespeare, the
The cunning artist, you know, makes it relevant by having Hamlet to speak, you know, about what's Hecua to him, or, you know, you could cut that out, and not that anybody would want to.
I think no difference.
Well, as George had said, would he have wanted a thousand luck?
Would he have wanted a thousand?
Yeah.
Yes, that's right.
Sufflaminandles, yes.
Sufflaminandles.
How would you think?
What would you ask him about?
What would you like to know?
I know it's a damn silly question.
I'd like to know about the dark lady.
Who was the dark lady and how dark was she?
You'd get right to it.
Would you be interested in the second best beds?
No, I think I can explain that.
I don't think there's really any need to ask a question, because if Susanna took over the best bedroom, which she would have to, Anne, as the dowager,
could automatically take the second best bed.
It's a matter of the call of heaven.
In any case, the second best bed must have been the bed they had when they were married.
It wasn't necessarily a nasty slap at her, the second best bed.
But she was entitled to that anyway.
Your questions wouldn't be then literary or creative.
God, I'm absolutely convinced he would give you no answer.
You try, however, I'm sure.
I don't think I could.
What do you mean by this line, Master Shakespeare?
I don't know.
I'm sure.
Well, I think this... What I would be most interested in, thankfully, would be listening to his voice.
People tend to forget that Shakespeare had a voice.
Shakespeare himself was an actor.
I'd like to know how good an actor he was, how he used his voice.
And to check whether my own, well, not my own, but linguistic suppositions as to how he spoke are correct.
I think they probably are.
I can give you a fairly good imitation of Shakespeare's voice myself.
Oh, please.
Oh, really?
Well, you know, Shakespeare played... All right, then.
Well, Hamlet, anyway.
To be or not to be, that is the question.
Whether it is nobler in the mind to suffer with slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles and by opposing end.
It's closer to New England than to New England.
And they spoke very rapidly.
Very rapidly.
Very rapidly.
So when you said the two-hour traffic of this stage, it takes us three and a half to four hours to do a thorough Hamlet...
I directed it myself once.
It took two nights.
It took two hours per night.
Four hours per night.
But... English was spoken rapidly on the stage until these Victorians like Henry Irving began to slow it down.
It was partly because of the size of the theatres in London.
The Theatre Regulating Act...
a limited serious drama to two theatres.
These were the Theatre Royal at Glory Lane and the one at Covent Garden.
They were very big, they were very big theatres.
And so they had to develop a technique whereby every word was clear of the bag.
This meant speaking very slowly.
And the technique went on into Victorian times with Henry Irving and Beardbone Tree, you know, to be or not to be, you know, that sort of thing.
Then the man who changed all was Harley Grandel Barker.
He suddenly said, back to rapidity of speech, and they said, well, supposing we can't understand this, but that's not the point.
That's not the point at all.
There's a lot of Shakespeare you can't understand, unless you look at it, look at the text.
But he said, the speed, the speed, and he was right.
I don't know whether America's really picked up that point, but the Royal Shakespeare company picked it up.
And I'm pretty sure that Shakespeare spoke rapidly, rather like an Italian, not like an American.
Americans speak slowly.
I don't know where they get this from.
Do you think he was a good actor?
No, I don't either.
A louty actor, probably.
But he was listed, of course.
He had quite a place in it.
Well, he's got his mind, I think, probably.
He played the ghost in Hamlet, the ghost.
Yeah, that's what I think they say.
He played in Ben Johnson's Janus, or part of that, I don't know.
And he played in Every Man in His Humor.
Um, I think he was probably a good middle, he would never win an Oscar, not like Ben Kingsley, but, you know, couldn't be bothered to learn the line.
How about visualizing real people like this, in terms of having fictional work as you can, or even in more contemporary type people, Freudian class people?
What kind of problems do you face with this?
Well, you've got to pretend there are no problems, otherwise you'd never do it right.
You've got to make a very bold step, take a very bold step.
Is it making a new character, or do you try a new character?
Well, I think most of the characters become one's self, in the sense that you're approaching them to be inside, which means it's your inside.
But what worries me very frequently is the speech rhythms they use.
The idiom is that they tend to be my own.
That's what worries me.
I end up with a bunch of characters who are a bit too like me to be as if acceptable.
But I think that's fairly common.
I think the scenes with Freud and his wife are a pricey.
I don't know whether it happened or not.
I don't know.
I just don't know.
I wish he's trying to shut him up when he says a couple of times.
What do you mean about sex?
Oh, no.
What do you mean about probably too?
Do you think of anything except sex?
No.
I mean, about probably too.
And then he brings in the Oedipus.
That's right.
You've translated that.
That's my translation, that's my translation.
Is this a matter of employing material that you're... To give the critics notice, they never do.
No, but it's easy, obviously, to use your... As you get older, you know, you have a hell of a lot of stuff behind you, and why not utilize something to do?
I do a lot of this cheating, but you as a journalist will understand this.
When somebody dies...

let me ask you that i'm asked for a quick victory let's see if i've written anything in the past sure well the clips we call it in our business we say pull the clips that's right pretend i'm writing it for the first time nobody knows nobody interesting about jakes with are you um
Have you studied this question of Shakespeare's speech, the way they actually spoke English?
I'm sorry, sir.
Have you studied the way that they actually spoke?

I haven't, I'm sure there is a... But there's a kind of, on the part of a lot of American actors, there's a sort of false reverence, you know, for people like Olivia and John Gilbert, whereas American speech, especially in this area, would...
come far closer to what shape we're actually used.
The origin of the local streets of Plymouth is pretty far west, but close enough to Stratford.
I have read that as a matter of fact.

there is a book that came out from oxford about two years ago very forbidding intimidating well it can be but it's got to be approached much more humanly but it's a combination of dublin dublin speech and and
You know, if one goes to Dublin, you'll hear the same vowel sounds.
Irish speaks much more conservative than British.
American speaks as conservative, but British is not.
It's strange, I don't know why.
I don't know why.
I mean, the British are conservative.
Conservative people, the Americans are not.
I don't think so.
Well, Americans are very progressive.
I don't know.
I think we tend to be very conservative at our level.
We seem to have demonstrated this several times in the last few months.
No, you make things.
The new things come from America, don't they?
The new thing.
We're always the West for new things.
And we get them.
I don't mean new technology, but new philosophers.
The new philosophers come with you.
You know, this is ridiculous, I must have some time.
If you want more coffee, if you do... How about the exercise in writing science fiction?
Oh, that's not science fiction, but... It's a very loose term.
The whole point about that segment, it's not science fiction.
It's about people, it's not about machines.
It's about people.
Is that what science fiction is, though?
It's about machines?
It's very rarely about people.
But what I wanted to do, I could do it, I didn't have the skill,
write in the manner of Henry James, you see, about people facing, you know, the final catechism.
Of course, if you did write in the style of Henry James, the final catechism would disappear entirely.
It would become irrelevant.
Which it is, in a sense.
It's not, you know, the end of the world is not very interesting, is it?
Well, he doesn't really believe in it.
He doesn't really believe in it.
I don't believe in it either.
No do I, I don't read it.
I find most of it very, very dull.
Very dull written.
Well, because it lacks character.
I think it's it.
The best one is still, well, the best.
Could I have some more tea, please?
Could I have some strong tea?
I mean, Boston usually has the best tea in the world.
All you give me is one tea bag.
I'll tell you, we're going to take care of you.
That's right.
You got the wrong weight.
I'm not a weight.
I'm sorry.
I know that.
I'd like some more glasses.
Thank you very much.
H.G.

Wells is still the best, you know, I think because, you know, the war of the world is good, totally typical, but what is interesting in that book is people, especially, there's one old man in the book who says, you know, right, they're going to destroy the world, and
Fingers will never be as they was before.
I remember you could buy tinned salmon once, you know, and eat it with vinegar.
That's it.
The taste buds.
Do you ever have a comment in there that, in a way, how that was could be seen as a form of science fiction?
I'm sure that... He attempts a definition of science fiction.
I don't think it's right.
I think it begins with Daniel Defoe.
I believe that.
It begins with Daniel Defoe's, God bless you, sir.
Just you will make up for the last one.
You're very kind.
Thank you.
The Journal of the Plague, yes?
By Daniel Defoe.
Which I haven't read, I need to say.
No, there's no need to.
Well, you'd like it anyway.
You know, pick it up.
You'll like it.
It's science fiction in that.
It's about an event which nobody's prepared for, which obviously requires a scientific response.
It doesn't get it.
People are not capable of coping with the organic matter.
You don't know what it is.
You don't know how to cure it.
And what happens to a whole city, a whole vast group of people, how they respond to it?

And the remarkable thing about the book is that you think that it's a journalistic record, and you suddenly realise that Petrol was born in 1660, with only, what, five, when the Great Patriot happened.
And it's a cunning journalistic job, you know, he's read the document, pretended he was there,
and dished it up in a very unflowering style.
You can hear the rattle the tide by the way.
A fast job.
A fast job, without chapter division.
No chapter division, no time for that.
Straight on playing the way.

80 pages and it's a great man well it feels generally it feels real generally your book i we actually see the switches i mean we don't you don't announce that we're going from from the the problem of links before and then on to trotsky oh well we just we just move immediately immediately we switch occasionally there's a link
what the television used to call blue.
It's very, very occasional.
But it looks very arbitrary.
In a sense it is arbitrary.
But if you look more closely you'll find you have the three major narrative forms.
You have the Broadway musical which is a major narrative form.
You have the television serial and you have the novels.
You have three
three events which seem to me to be possibly the most important event.
The American discovery of the possibility of living in space, the unconscious, which is the same as space, and the possibility of creating a world of social society
which is so impossible.
It goes a bit deeper.
That's a wonderful... True.
I love the fact that you wrote your own dust jacket for it.
Well, that again is probably a trick, but when the book came out, something railing about

some of the dust jacket verbs that you need it's very embarrassing either the person who has written or hasn't read the book or has read it and has decided to give you everything it happens sometimes if you're reviewing it won't be very grateful if you're pressed and the deadline is on on you and you need something but i know immediately when my reviewers have about 80 people who review for me
How many books do you review?
You do all the books you're doing, do you?
No, I have a page every Sunday for which I assign three-way.
We've already reviewed your book on my Sunday page.
Oh, God bless you, sir.
God bless you.
It may sell two or three copies, you know.
There's a fellow who reviewed it did a wonderful job.
I gave it a nice two-way, tiny three-way novel.
There's a lot of two-way tugging.
Well, no, the other thing, I'm very grateful, really.
Sincerely.
And then my piece will run next week in the evening paper.
Really good.
But we do about ten books a week anyway.
It's a lot.
Well, I know what life was like.
When I came back from Malaya with a death sentence, I'd been given a year to live, but this was commuted to life.
I saw life.
I had a difficult job of earning a living as a writer during that terminal year, pseudo-terminal year, and I wrote five and a half novels.
The following year... In that one year, five and a half novels?
Well, it is possible.
I mean, indeed, I ended up by writing... What year was it?
I ended up writing my 2,000 daily words before breakfast, up the day to myself, which is possible if you don't write too carefully.
Nobody cares.
No, the point I was going to make was this, that I got my first journalistic, my, yes, my first posthumous journalistic job with the Yorkshire Post, which is a paper you won't know.
It's a very old British paper.
It's published in Leeds in Yorkshire.
It's hard-headed, you know, in Yorkshire.
And they gave me the job of reviewing all the fiction.
And I had no idea at the time what this entailed.
I had no idea how much fiction I published.
They paid me six pounds, which was what, about ten dollars?
Ten dollars an hour to live on that.
They got all the books.
All of them.
And it is quite incredible.
You're going to see my library after five years.
Well, you sell them.
You sell them.
You sell them.
I keep what I... Well, you keep selling them.
Well, I don't sell them.
I'll be honest with you.
I get my access to the public library.
Well, you're a gentleman, but... I was a bit... I'm also careful.
Well, I was a bit worried.
I was a bit worried about money then.
And every other Monday, I used to fill two suitcases with books.
And the village where I was living inside... All was said the same thing.
And there were all persuasions.
Well, indeed.
I realize that now.
Like a bloody fool.
I was given a lot of persuasion for money.
Like an idiot.
I used to go to the States.
They always said to me, he's leaving his wife again.
I had no memory of it.

I'd take them to Charling Cross Station in London and get off on the Strand and walk up the Strand of Feet Street, where the only Jewish bookseller in London, I'm called Lewis Simmons, and he would buy these books half-bought.
It'd give you notes, banknotes, new, fresh banknotes, lovely, clean crevices, which were yours.
It was your money, my money.
You'd walk back to the station and buy a bottle of brandy on the way with choice cigars.
That was marvellous.
I've never had that since.
I meant for me, you said you were under a death sentence for a year.
Did you tell me what you mean by that?
Well, I was working in...
In Borneo, in the north, there are three terraces there.
Sarawak, British North Borneo, which has changed to Sabah.
It's called Sabah.
And in the middle, there's a little sultanate called Brunei.
Brunei is the Malay name, or Borneo.
And this was run by sultan and family.
And they discovered oil.
They discovered oil.
